standardDescription: Understand a fraction 1/b as the quantity formed by 1 part when a whole is partitioned into b equal parts; understand a fraction a/b as the quantity formed by a parts of size 1/b.
subject: fractions

masteryGoals.description: Student can physically or visually divide a shape (circle, rectangle, bar) into b equal-sized parts (where b = 2, 3, 4, or 6)
assessmentCriteria: Divides a circle into 2, 3, or 4 equal parts using lines from center
Divides a rectangle into 2, 3, 4, or 6 equal parts using evenly-spaced lines
Can explain WHY parts are equal (same size, same area, same amount)
Uses visual strategies (symmetry, measurement, folding) to ensure equality
evidenceOfMastery: Student draws dividing lines that create equal parts
Student can check their work by comparing part sizes
Student adjusts unequal partitions when prompted
Student transfers skill across different shapes
commonErrors: Creates unequal parts but doesn't notice

scaffolding.low: Show me how to divide this circle into 2 equal parts. Use a line from top to bottom!
scaffolding.medium: Draw a circle and divide it into 3 equal parts. How can you check they're equal?
scaffolding.high: Choose any shape and partition it into equal fourths. Explain your strategy.

masteryGoals.goal: Recognize that fractions require equal parts
masteryGoals.description: Student understands that fractions can ONLY describe situations where a whole is divided into equal-sized parts, and can discriminate equal from unequal partitioning
assessmentCriteria: Identifies when a partitioned shape does NOT show equal parts
Explains why unequal parts cannot be called fractions
Rejects incorrect fraction labels on unequal partitions
Articulates the 'equal parts rule' in their own words
evidenceOfMastery: Student correctly identifies unequal partitions in checkpoint task
Student says 'those can't be thirds because they're different sizes'
Student critiques incorrect examples with reasoning
Student checks their own work for equal-ness before labeling fractions
commonErrors: Focuses on number of parts, not size of parts
Accepts unequal partitions as valid fractions

scaffolding.low: Look at these pieces - are they ALL the same size? If not, can we call them fractions?
scaffolding.medium: Is this really one-fourth? How can you tell if the parts are equal?
scaffolding.high: Someone says this is 1/3. Are they correct? Prove your answer.

masteryGoals.goal: Understand unit fractions as 'one part out of b equal parts'
masteryGoals.description: Student grasps that a unit fraction (1/b) represents taking ONE of the equal parts when a whole is divided into b equal parts
assessmentCriteria: Can identify 'one part' when shown a partitioned whole
Connects the idea of 'one piece' to fraction language (one-third, one-fourth)
Understands that ALL unit fractions follow this pattern (1/2, 1/3, 1/4, 1/6)
Can explain what 1/b means in concrete terms
evidenceOfMastery: Student correctly identifies 'one-third' as one of three equal parts
Student can generate unit fraction names (one-half, one-fourth, one-sixth)
Student explains 'each friend gets one-third' in sharing context
Student connects visual representation to unit fraction concept
commonErrors: Confuses unit fraction with the whole
Doesn't connect fraction to equal partitioning

scaffolding.low: If we cut into 3 equal parts, each part is called... what?
scaffolding.medium: Point to one-third in this picture. Now tell me what one-third means.
scaffolding.high: Create your own example of one-fifth and explain what it represents.

masteryGoals.goal: Understand denominator as 'total number of equal parts'
masteryGoals.description: Student understands that the bottom number (denominator) in a fraction tells HOW MANY equal parts the whole is divided into
assessmentCriteria: Can identify the denominator in fraction notation (1/3, 1/4, etc.)
Explains that denominator = number of equal parts in the whole
Connects denominator to the partitioning action (divided into 4 → denominator is 4)
Can predict denominator by counting equal parts in a visual
evidenceOfMastery: Student says 'the 3 in 1/3 means we cut it into 3 equal pieces'
Student writes correct denominator when shown partitioned shape
Student can answer 'Why is the bottom number 4?' with correct reasoning
Student connects symbolic notation to visual representation
commonErrors: Thinks denominator is 'how many we have'
Can't explain what the bottom number represents

scaffolding.low: See this 1/3? The bottom number is 3. What does that 3 tell us?
scaffolding.medium: If I divide a circle into 6 equal parts, what will the bottom number be?
scaffolding.high: Why is the denominator 4 in this picture? Connect the visual to the symbol.

masteryGoals.goal: Understand numerator as 'number of parts we have'
masteryGoals.description: Student understands that the top number (numerator) in a fraction tells HOW MANY of those equal parts we're talking about
assessmentCriteria: Can identify the numerator in fraction notation
Explains that numerator = number of parts we're counting or have
Distinguishes between numerator (parts we have) and denominator (total parts)
For unit fractions, recognizes numerator is always 1
evidenceOfMastery: Student says 'the 1 in 1/3 means we have 1 of those pieces'
Student can explain both top and bottom numbers correctly
Student recognizes pattern: unit fractions always have numerator 1
Student connects notation to real-world context (1 piece out of 3 total)
commonErrors: Thinks top number is total parts
Doesn't see connection between 1 (top) and 'one piece'

scaffolding.low: In 1/4, what does the top number (1) mean?
scaffolding.medium: If each friend gets one piece, why is the numerator 1?
scaffolding.high: Explain why unit fractions always have 1 on top.

masteryGoals.goal: Connect symbolic notation to visual representations
masteryGoals.description: Student can fluently move between fraction symbols (1/3) and visual diagrams (circle divided into 3 equal parts with 1 shaded)
assessmentCriteria: Given a symbol (1/4), can draw correct visual representation
Given a visual, can write correct fraction notation
Explains how symbol and visual connect
Can identify mismatches between notation and visual
evidenceOfMastery: Student draws accurate visual when given 1/3
Student writes 1/6 when shown appropriate diagram
Student catches errors (e.g., unequal parts labeled as 1/4)
Student uses both representations interchangeably
commonErrors: Writes fraction that doesn't match visual

scaffolding.low: Show me what 1/2 looks like. Draw it!
scaffolding.medium: What fraction does this diagram show? Write the symbol.
scaffolding.high: Is this diagram really showing 1/4? Why or why not?

masteryGoals.goal: Transfer and generalize across contexts and shapes
masteryGoals.description: Student demonstrates deep understanding by applying fraction concepts to new shapes, situations, and self-chosen contexts; can articulate invariant principles
assessmentCriteria: Can partition ANY shape (including irregular ones) into equal parts
Applies understanding to self-chosen contexts (student picks shape, fraction)
Articulates the invariant rule: 'equal parts ALWAYS means same size, regardless of shape'
Demonstrates metacognition about their own understanding
evidenceOfMastery: Student successfully partitions triangle, hexagon, or other non-standard shape
Student explains their reasoning and strategy
Student says things like 'It doesn't matter what shape, they have to be equal'
Student teaches back the concept to demonstrate full understanding

scaffolding.low: Try dividing this new shape into equal parts. What strategy will you use?
scaffolding.medium: Pick your own shape and fraction. Show me 1/3 of your shape.
scaffolding.high: What's the ONE rule that's always true about fractions, no matter what?

stages.description: Connecting visuals to fraction language and concepts
Understanding symbolic notation and its meaning
Applying to new contexts and articulating principles

fullMastery: Student can partition any shape into b equal parts
Student correctly uses fraction notation with understanding
Student can explain what numerator and denominator represent
Student transfers understanding to novel contexts
Student can teach concept to others
partialMastery: Student can partition simple shapes (circles, rectangles) into equal parts
Student uses some fraction language correctly
Student needs scaffolding for symbolic notation
emerging: Student attempts partitioning but creates unequal parts
Student struggles to explain fraction meaning

metadata.author: Simili Pedagogy Team
metadata.notes: Mastery goals ladder from concrete partitioning to abstract understanding to transfer and generalization. Each goal has clear assessment criteria and scaffolding levels.
